lead_paragraph: They met in 1929, in the photographer's shop where she worked, in Munich. He was 40, she was 17. He devoured her with his eyes, she said. Soon after, he had her family investigated, to check that her bloodlines were Aryan. He was Adolf Hitler, an amateur artist whose charisma as a reactionary orator had propelled him to the forefront of Germany's National Socialist party. She was Eva Braun, an attractive blonde from a middle-class family who, after one year at a school run by nuns, was back home living with her parents. We know how the story ends, though we can't help wondering why - was she completely lacking in intelligence, or morals, or both? In "Eva Braun: Life With Hitler," translated from the German by Damion Searls (Alfred A. Knopf), Heike B. Görtemaker takes on a task few biographers - I'm tempted to say no biographer in her right mind - would tackle, so scant and unreliable is the material.
